{{Infobox NRHP | name = Albright-Knox Art Gallery | image = Albright-Knox Art Gallery 1.jpg | caption = | image_size = 300px | location = 1285 Elmwood Avenue, [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | coordinates = {{coord|42.93245|-78.87563|type:landmark_region:US-NY|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | area = | built = 1890–1905, 1962 (addition) | architect = [[Augustus St. Gaudens|Augustus Saint Gaudens]], [[Edward Brodhead Green]]<ref name=nrhp>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalregisterofhistoricplaces.com/NY/Erie/state.html|title=National Register of Historical Places - New York (NY), Erie County|date=2007-02-24|work=National Register of Historic Places|publisher=National Park Service}}</ref> | architecture = [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux arts]]<ref name=nrhp/> | added = May 27, 1971 | refnum = 71000538<ref name=nrhp/> | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = Private }} The '''Albright–Knox Art Gallery''' is an [[art museum]] located at 1285 Elmwood Avenue, [[Buffalo, New York]], in [[Delaware Park-Front Park System|Delaware Park]]. The gallery is a major showplace for [[modern art]] and [[contemporary art]]. It is located directly opposite [[Buffalo State College]] and the [[Burchfield Penney Art Center]].
==History== [[Image:20070223 AlbrightKnox Art Gallery.JPG|thumb|left|View from Elmwood Avenue]] [[Image:Inside Albright Knox.jpg|thumb|250px|View from inside]] The parent organization of the Albright–Knox Art Gallery is the Buffalo Fine Arts Academy, founded in 1862. It is one of the oldest public arts institutions in the United States. In 1890, Buffalo entrepreneur and philanthropist, [[John J. Albright]], a wealthy [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]] industrialist, began the construction of the Albright Art Gallery for the Academy. The building was designed by prominent local architect [[Edward Brodhead Green]]. It was originally intended to be used as the Fine Arts Pavilion for the [[Pan-American Exposition]] in 1901, but delays in its construction caused it to remain uncompleted until 1905.<!-- Unsourced image removed: [[Image:Lawn logo2.jpg|thumb|right]] --><ref name="NysNrhpNom">{{cite web|url=https://cris.parks.ny.gov/ |title=Cultural Resource Information System (CRIS) |publisher=[[New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation]] |format=Searchable database |accessdate=2016-07-01 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''Note:'' This includes {{cite web|url=https://cris.parks.ny.gov/Uploads/ViewDoc.aspx?mode=A&id=29582&q=false |title=National Register of Historic Places Registration Form: Albright–Knox Art Gallery |accessdate=2016-07-01 |author=Diane S. Waite |format=PDF |date=September 1975 }} and [https://cris.parks.ny.gov/Uploads/ViewDoc.aspx?mode=A&id=29581&q=false ''Accompanying photographs'']</ref>
In 1962, a new addition was made to the gallery through the contributions of [[Seymour H. Knox II|Seymour H. Knox, Jr.]] and his family, and many other donors. At this time the museum was renamed the Albright–Knox Art Gallery. The new building was designed by [[Skidmore, Owings and Merrill]] architect [[Gordon Bunshaft]], who is noted for the [[Lever House]] in New York City. The Albright–Knox Art Gallery is listed in the [[National Register of Historic Places]].
The museum first began discussing a possible expansion in 2001. In 2012, the board commissioned the architectural firm [[Snøhetta]] to produce a master plan for future growth.<ref name="theartnewspaper.com">Julia Halperin (October 22, 2014), [http://theartnewspaper.com/articles/Buffalos-jewelbox-art-museum-to-grow/36033 Buffalo’s jewel-box art museum to grow] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141023233304/http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Buffalos-jewelbox-art-museum-to-grow/36033 |date=2014-10-23 }} ''[[The Buffalo News]]''.</ref> In 2014, the board voted to initiate a museum expansion and, in June 2016, the museum announced its selection of OMA as the architect for the project. Doubleline CEO and Buffalo native Jeffrey Gundlach has pledged $42.5 million to the project, while businesses, foundations, government groups, and individuals have promised matching funds toward a $125 million goal.
==Exhibitions== In 1978, the Gallery's exhibition on the work of [[Richard Diebenkorn]] was chosen to represent the United States at the 28th [[Venice Biennale]]. In 1988, the museum again won the competition to organize the exhibition representing the United States in Venice; the museum's curator Michael G. Auping proposed media artist [[Jenny Holzer]].<ref>Michael Brenson (July 27, 1988), [https://www.nytimes.com/1988/07/27/arts/media-artist-named-to-represent-us-at-90-venice-biennale.html Media Artist Named To Represent U.S. At '90 Venice Biennale] ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref>
==Collection== [[File:Albert Gleizes, 1913, L'Homme au hamac, oil on canvas, 130 x 155.5 cm. Albright-Knox Art Gallery, Buffalo, New York.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Albert Gleizes]], ''[[Man in a Hammock|L'Homme au Hamac (Man in a Hammock)]]'' (1913)]] The Albright–Knox Art Gallery has long operated not by collecting artists' work in depth but by trying to acquire key works.<ref name="nytimes.com">Randy Kennedy (March 14, 2007), [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/14/arts/design/14albr.html Buffalo’s Pain: Giving Up Old Art to Gain New] ''The New York Times''.</ref> The gallery's collection includes several pieces spanning art throughout the centuries. [[Impressionism|Impressionistic]] and [[Impressionism|Post-Impressionistic]] styles can be found in works by artists of the nineteenth century such as [[Paul Gauguin]] and [[Vincent van Gogh]].
Revolutionary styles from the early twentieth century such as [[cubism]], [[surrealism]], [[Constructivism (art)|constructivism]] are represented in works by artists like [[Pablo Picasso]], [[Georges Braque]], [[Jean Metzinger]], [[Albert Gleizes]], [[Henri Matisse]], [[André Derain]], [[Joan Miró]], [[Piet Mondrian]], and [[Alexander Rodchenko]]. [[Frida Kahlo]] is represented by ''[[Self-Portrait with Monkey]]''. Because of Seymour H. Knox and Gordon M. Smith, a former director, the Albright-Knox was one of the first museums to collect Abstract Expressionism in depth.<ref>Michael Brenson (October 18, 1987), [https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/18/arts/art-view-when-america-put-its-stamp-on-world-painting.html When America Put Its Stamp On World Painting] ''The New York Times''.</ref>
More modern pieces showing styles of [[abstract expressionism]], [[pop art]], and art of the 1970s through the end of the century can also be found represented by artists such as [[Arshile Gorky]], [[Jackson Pollock]], [[Clyfford Still]], and [[Andy Warhol]]. Additionally, the gallery is also rich in various pieces of [[Contemporary art|post-war]] American and [[European art]];<ref>"History of Albright-Knox Art Gallery", [http://www.albrightknox.org/GenInfo/history.html Albrightknox.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218221217/http://www.albrightknox.org/GenInfo/history.html |date=2008-12-18 }}, 23 September 2008</ref> their contemporary collection includes pieces by artists such as [[Kiki Smith]], [[Allan Graham]], [[Georg Baselitz]], [[John Connell]], and [[Per Kirkeby]]. The museum bought [[Anselm Kiefer]]'s large-scale ''Die Milchstrasse (The Milkyway)'' (1985–87) in 1988 to celebrate its 125th anniversary.<ref>Colin Dabkowski (August 24, 2013), [http://www.buffalonews.com/life-arts/albright-knox-buys-mammoth-painting-by-german-artist-anselm-kiefer-20130824 Albright-Knox buys mammoth painting by German artist Anselm Kiefer] ''[[The Buffalo News]]''.</ref>
The Albright-Knox's current exhibition space can accommodate only 200 works — just 3% of its 6,740-piece collection.<ref name="theartnewspaper.com"/>
==Selected collection highlights==
===Paintings=== <gallery widths="220px" heights="220px" perrow="4"> File:Honoré Daumier - Laundress on the Quai d'Anjou - WGA05958.jpg|[[Honoré Daumier]], ''Laundress on the Quai d'Anjou'', c. 1860 File:Jacques-Louis David - Portrait of Jacques-François Desmaisons - WGA06048.jpg|[[Jacques-Louis David]], ''Portrait of Jacques-François Desmaisons,'' 1782 File:Delaunay Soleil Tor Aeroplane 1913.jpg|[[Robert Delaunay]], ''Soleil, Tour, Aéroplane'' (''Sun, Tower, Airplane''), 1913 File:Eakins, Music 1904.jpg|[[Thomas Eakins]], ''Music'', 1904 File:Thomas Gainsborough - Portrait of Miss Evans.jpg|[[Thomas Gainsborough]], ''Portrait of Miss Evans,'' c. 1786-1790 File:Gauguin Il Cristo giallo.jpg|[[Paul Gauguin]], ''[[The Yellow Christ]]'', 1889 File:Paul Gauguin- Manao tupapau (The Spirit of the Dead Keep Watch).JPG|[[Paul Gauguin]], ''[[Spirit of the Dead Watching]]'' 1892 File:Albert Gleizes, 1913, L'Homme au hamac, oil on canvas, 130 x 155.5 cm. Albright-Knox Art Gallery, Buffalo, New York.jpg|[[Albert Gleizes]], ''[[Man in a Hammock|L'Homme au Hamac (Man in a Hammock)]]'', 1913, oil on canvas, 130 x 155.5 cm File:William Hogarth - The Lady's last stake, c.1759.jpg|[[William Hogarth]], ''[[The Lady's Last Stake]]'', 1759 File:Winslow Homer - Croquet Players.jpg|[[Winslow Homer]], ''Croquet Players'', 1865 Image:Jean Metzinger, 1912, Danseuse au café, Dancer in a café, oil on canvas, 146.1 x 114.3 cm, Albright-Knox Art Gallery, Buffalo, New York.jpg|[[Jean Metzinger]], 1912, ''Danseuse au café'' (''[[Dancer in a café]]''), oil on canvas, 146.1 x 114.3 cm. Exhibited at the 1912 Salon d'Automne File:Pierre-Auguste Renoir 056.jpg|[[Pierre-Auguste Renoir]], ''Small Nude in Blue'', 1879 File:Joshua Reynolds - Cupid as Link Boy.jpg|[[Joshua Reynolds]] ''Cupid as Link Boy'', c. 1771-1777 File:Henri Rousseau - Bouquet of Flowers with an Ivy Branch.jpg|[[Henri Rousseau]], ''Bouquet of Flowers with an Ivy Branch,'' 1909 File:Alfred Sisley - Rue de village à Marlotte, 1866.jpg|[[Alfred Sisley]], ''Village Street in Marlotte'', 1866 File:Vincent van Gogh - La Maison de la Crau.jpg|[[Vincent van Gogh]], ''La Maison de la Crau'' (''The Old Mill''), 1888 </gallery>
The Albright-Knox has more than 6,500 works in its collection, below is a list highlighting a few other notable paintings:<ref name="Collection Highlights">{{cite web | url=http://www.albrightknox.org/collection/collection-highlights/ | title=Collection Highlights | publisher=Albright-Knox Art Gallery | accessdate=April 6, 2012}}</ref>

===Sculptures=== The gallery contains a variety of sculptures on the exterior grounds. Some of the most notable, from the past and the present, include:

Column'' || [[Kenneth Snelson]] || 1969–81 || |- style="vertical-align:top; text-align:center; background:#f8f8ff;" | ''Flat Rate II'' || [[Lyman Kipp]] || 1969 || |- style="vertical-align:top; text-align:center; background:#f8f8ff;" | ''Four Chances'' || [[Kenneth Snelson]] || 1982 || |- style="vertical-align:top; text-align:center; background:#f8f8ff;" | ''Into the Blue'' || [[Shayne Dark]] || 2005 || |- style="vertical-align:top; text-align:center; background:#f8f8ff;" | ''Laura'' || [[Jaume Plensa]]|| 2012 || |- style="vertical-align:top; text-align:center; background:#f8f8ff;" | ''Look and See'' || [[Jim Hodges (artist)|Jim Hodges]]|| 2005 || |- style="vertical-align:top; text-align:center; background:#f8f8ff;" | ''Shark Girl'' || [[Casey Riordan Millard]] || 2014 || |- style="vertical-align:top; text-align:center; background:#f8f8ff;" | ''Stacked Revision Structure'' || [[Liam Gillick]] || 2005 || |- style="vertical-align:top; text-align:center; background:#f8f8ff;" | ''The Cry'' || [[Isamu Noguchi]]|| 1962 || |- style="vertical-align:top; text-align:center; background:#f8f8ff;" | ''Turning the World Upside Down #4'' || [[Anish Kapoor]] || 1998 || |}
==Deaccessioning and the Albright-Knox's mission== [[File:Artemis Met Museum.jpg|thumb|''[[Artemis and the Stag]]'', on display at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]].]] In 2007, the Albright–Knox Art Gallery deaccessioned a Roman-era bronze sculpture, ''[[Artemis and the Stag]]'', that was auctioned at [[Sotheby's|Sotheby's New York]] on June 7, 2007, and brought $28.6 million.<ref>[http://buffalonews.typepad.com/inside_the_news/2007/06/artemis_fetches.html"Artemis" fetches a staggering sum" ''The Buffalo News'', 7 June 2007]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Accessed 3 September 2008;</ref> This was the highest price ever paid at auction for an antiquity or a sculpture of any period, according to Sotheby's. It was purchased by the London dealer [[Giuseppe Eskenazi]] on behalf of a private European collector.<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1248/is_8_95/ai_n20511369 "Albright-Knox rakes it in", ''Art In America'', September 2007].</ref>
The event brought national attention to what until then had been a local question, the mission of the Albright-Knox. In February 2007, when the list of works to be [[Collection (museum)#Deaccessioning|deaccessioned]] was made public, Albright-Knox Director Louis Grachos defined the ancient sculpture as falling outside the institution's historical "core mission" of "acquiring and exhibiting art of the present." This definition made public critics wonder whether the position at the Gallery of "[[William Hogarth]]'s ''Lady's Last Stake'' or [[Sir Joshua Reynolds]]' ''Cupid as a Link Boy'' were secure. Works by [[Gustave Courbet]], [[Honoré Daumier]], [[Jacques-Louis David]] and [[Eugène Delacroix]] had been purchased by the museum in earlier decades.<ref>[http://www.artsjournal.com/culturegrrl/2007/02/mission_creep_albrightknox_bel.html Lee Rosenbaum, "Mission Creep: Albright-Knox Belatedly Releases Its Complete Deaccession List" Arts Journal'']</ref>
The decision to [[Collection (museum)#Deaccessioning|deaccession]] certain art works was made by a vote of the museum's Board of Directors, was voted on and ratified by the entire membership, and followed the guidelines of the [[American Alliance of Museums]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://artvoice.com/issues/v6n8/war_against_the_albright_knox |title=Archived copy |accessdate=March 2, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100201064312/http://artvoice.com/issues/v6n8/war_against_the_albright_knox |archivedate=February 1, 2010 }}</ref> The sale raised questions about how museums can remain vital when they are situated in economically declining regions and have limited means for raising funds for operations and acquisitions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artsjournal.com/man/2007/03/reexamining_deaccessioning_at.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=March 2, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081123012835/http://www.artsjournal.com/man/2007/03/reexamining_deaccessioning_at.html |archivedate=November 23, 2008 }}</ref>
==Hours== The gallery is open from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., Tuesday through Sunday. On the first Friday of each month, the gallery is open from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. with free admission to the permanent collection through the support of [[M&T Bank]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.albrightknox.org/visit/hours-admission/ |title=Hours & Admission |publisher=Albright–Knox Art Gallery |accessdate=August 6, 2016}}</ref>
==Management== [[File:Albright-Knox Art Gallery 2.jpg|thumb|300px|View from Delaware Park]]
===Governance=== Since 2013, Janne Sirén has been director of the Albright–Knox Art Gallery. Sirén is believed to be the first director from the Nordic region to take the helm of a major American art museum.<ref>Carol Vogel (January 14, 2013), [http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/01/14/buffalos-albright-knox-gets-a-director-from-much-farther-north/ Buffalo’s Albright-Knox Gets a Director from Much Farther North] ''The New York Times''.</ref>
Complete list of directors: * Janne Gallen-Kallela-Sirén (2013–present) * Louis Grachos (2002-2013) * Douglas G. Schultz (1983-2002) * Robert T. Buck, Jr. (1973-1983) * Gordon M. Smith (1955–1973) * Edgar C. Schenck (1949–1955) * Andrew C. Ritchie (1942–1949) * Gordon B. Washburn (1931–1942) * William M. Hekking (1925–1931) * [[Cornelia Bentley Sage Quinton]] (1910–1924) * Charles M. Kurtz (1905–1909)
===Funding=== As of 2007, the Albright–Knox Art Gallery's endowment stood at about $58 million, generating about $1.1 million a year for acquisitions.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> Since the proceeds from the sale of some 200 works of art in 2007 were added to the preexisting $22 million acquisitions endowment, the museum has been able to spend as much as almost $5 million on new art annually.<ref>Kevin West (November 2007), [http://www.wmagazine.com/culture/art-and-design/2007/11/contemporary_art/ In With The New - With contemporary art booming out of control, how can museums afford to play?] ''[[W (magazine)|W]]''.</ref> In 2013, the Albright–Knox Art Gallery received an $11 million bequest from the estate of longtime board member and Buffalo arts patron Peggy Pierce Elfvin, possibly the largest single gift in the museum's history.<ref>Colin Dabkowski (October 9, 2013), [http://www.buffalonews.com/gusto/art/buffalos-albright-knox-receives-11-million-bequest-from-ex-board-member-peggy-pierce-elfvin-20131009 Albright-Knox gets $11 million bequest from ex-board member Peggy Pierce Elfvin] ''[[Buffalo News]]''.</ref>

{{for|the English natural history illustrator|Anne Lister (illustrator)}} {{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Anne Lister | image = Lister anne.jpg | alt = | caption = Anne Lister, c. 1830. Portrait by Joshua Horner | birth_date = {{birth date|1791|04|03|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Halifax, West Yorkshire|Halifax]], United Kingdom | death_date = {{death date and age|1840|09|22|1791|04|03|df=y}} | death_place = [[Kutaisi]], Georgia | resting_place = St. Anne's Church [[Halifax Minster]] | nationality = British | other_names = | known_for = Diaries | occupation = Landowner }}
'''Anne Lister''' (1791–1840) was a well-off [[Yorkshire]] landowner, diarist, mountaineer and traveller. Throughout her life she kept diaries which chronicled the details of her daily life, including her lesbian relationships, her financial concerns, her industrial activities and her work improving [[Shibden Hall]].<ref name=BBCBradford>{{Citation | title = The life and loves of Shibden Hall's Anne Lister | work = [[BBC News]] | publisher = BBC | date = 25 May 2010 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/bradford/hi/people_and_places/history/newsid_8388000/8388858.stm | accessdate =6 June 2010 }}</ref> Her diaries contain more than 4,000,000 words and about a sixth of them—those concerning the intimate details of her romantic and sexual relationships—were written in code.<ref name=BBCBradford /> The code, derived from a combination of [[algebra]] and [[Ancient Greek]], was deciphered in the 1980s.<ref name=SFS>{{Citation | last = Brown | first = Jonathan (''[[The Independent]]'') | author-link = | title = BBC Unveils Drama About Gentleman Jack – 'The First Modern Lesbian' | newspaper = [[San Francisco Sentinel]] | date = 16 October 2009 | url = http://www.sanfranciscosentinel.com/?p=46261 | accessdate = 6 June 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110928085250/http://www.sanfranciscosentinel.com/?p=46261 | archivedate = 28 September 2011 | df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=dempster>{{Citation | last = Dempster | first = Sarah | title = The Secret Diary of Miss Anne Lister and 30 Rock | newspaper = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = [[Guardian Media Group]] | date = 1 June 2010 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2010/jun/01/secret-diary-miss-anne-lister | accessdate =4 June 2010 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100603194140/http://www.guardian.co.uk/tv-and-radio/2010/jun/01/secret-diary-miss-anne-lister| archivedate= 3 June 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> Lister is often called "the first modern lesbian" for her clear self-knowledge and openly lesbian lifestyle.<ref>{{cite web | last = Chafee | first = Ellen | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Lister, Anne (1791–1840) | work = glbtq: An Encyclopedia of Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual, Transgender, and Queer Culture | publisher = | year = 2002 | url = http://www.glbtq.com/literature/lister_a.html | accessdate = 16 March 2007 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070311020637/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/lister_a.html| archivedate= 11 March 2007 | deadurl= no}}</ref> Called "Fred" by her lover and "Gentleman Jack" by [[Halifax, West Yorkshire|Halifax]] residents, she suffered from harassment for her sexuality, and recognised her similarity to the [[Ladies of Llangollen]], whom she visited.<ref name="Review: The Pursuit of Love" />
==Life== [[File:James Lister (1748–1826).jpg|thumb|left|James Lister by Joshua Horner (1812–1884)]]
Anne Lister was a rural gentlewoman who directed the renovation and landscaping of Shibden Hall, near Halifax in the [[West Riding of Yorkshire]], which she had inherited from her uncle, James Lister.
Anne was the eldest daughter of [[Jeremy Lister]] (1753–1836), who as a young man in 1775 served with the British [[10th Regiment of Foot]] in the [[Battles of Lexington and Concord]] in the American War of Independence. In August 1788 he married Rebecca Battle (1770–1817) of Welton in East Riding, Yorkshire. Their first child, John, was born in 1789 but died the same year. Anne Lister was born in Halifax on 3 April 1791. In 1793 the family moved to an estate named Skelfler House at [[Market Weighton]]. Skelfler was where the young Anne Lister would spend her earliest years. A second son, Samuel, who would be a close friend to Anne, was born in 1793.<ref>{{cite book|last=Green|first=Muriel|title=Miss Lister of Shibden Hall: Selected Letters (1800–1840)|year=1992|publisher=The Book Guild, Ltd.|location=Sussex, England|isbn=0-86332-672-2|page=18}}</ref> The Listers had six children in total, but only Anne and her younger sister Marian survived to adulthood.
Between 1801 and 1805, Lister was educated at home by the Reverend George Skelding, the vicar of [[Market Weighton]], and at the age of seven she was sent to a school run by a Mrs Hagues and a Mrs Chettle in Agnesgate, Ripon. On her visits to her aunt Anne and uncle James at Shibden Hall, the Misses Mellin gave her lessons. In 1804 Anne Lister was sent to the Manor House School in [[York]] (in the [[King's Manor]] buildings), where Anne would meet her first love, Eliza Raine (1791–1869). Eliza and her sister Jane were the very rich daughters of an East India Company surgeon in Madras, brought to Yorkshire after his death. Anne and Eliza met and shared a bedroom aged 13 at boarding school, but Anne was asked to leave after two years. She rejoined the school after Eliza had left. Eliza expected to live with Anne as an adult, but Anne began affairs with Isabella Norcliffe and Mariana Belcombe, day-pupils at the school. In despair and frustration Eliza became a patient at Clifton Asylum, run by Mariana's father Dr Belcombe.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hughes|first=Patricia|title=The Early Life of Miss Anne Lister and the Curious Tale of Miss Eliza Raine|year=2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Green|first=Muriel|title=Miss Lister of Shibden Hall: Selected Letters (1800–1840)|year=1992|pages=7, 19}}</ref> While being educated at home Lister developed an interest in classical literature. In a surviving letter to her aunt from 3 February 1803, a young Lister explains "My library is my greatest pleasure... The Grecian History had please me much.<ref>{{cite book|last=Whitbread|first=Helena|title=No Priest but Love: Excerpts from the Diaries of Anne Lister, 1824–1826|year=1992|publisher=new York University Press|page=2}}</ref>
[[File:Shibden Hall and the South Terrace - geograph.org.uk - 1737340.jpg|thumb|left|250px|[[Shibden Hall]]]]
Her wealth allowed her some measure of freedom to live as she pleased. She inherited the family estate on her aunt's death in 1836, [[Shibden Hall]], but took charge of it from 1826,<ref name="BBC - The life and loves of Shibden Hall's Anne Lister">{{cite news|title=The life and loves of Shibden Hall's Anne Lister|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/bradford/hi/people_and_places/history/newsid_8388000/8388858.stm|accessdate=29 May 2010|newspaper=BBC|date=25 May 2010}}</ref> and from it drew a reasonable income (some of it from tenants).<ref name="BBC - The life and loves of Shibden Hall's Anne Lister" />
In addition to income from agricultural tenancy, Lister's financial portfolio included properties in town, shares in the canal and railway industries, mining and stone quarries. Anne Lister used the income from this varied portfolio to finance her two passions; Shibden Hall and European travel.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Liddington|first=Jill|title=Anne Lister of Shibden Hall, Halifax (1791-1840): Her Diaries and the Historians|journal=History Workshop Journal|date=1993|issue=35}}</ref>
Lister is described as having a "masculine appearance"; one of her lovers, Marianna Lawton (née Belcombe), was initially ashamed to be seen in public with her because her appearance was commented on.<ref name="Rictor - First Modern Lesbian">{{cite web|last=Norton|first=Rictor|title=Anne Lister: The First Modern Lesbian|url=http://rictornorton.co.uk/lister.htm|work=Lesbian History|accessdate=29 May 2010}}</ref> She dressed entirely in black<ref name="Review: The Pursuit of Love">{{cite journal|last=Castle|first=Terry|title=Review: The Pursuit of Love|journal=The Women's Review of Books |date=January 1989 |volume=6|issue=4|pages=6–7|doi=10.2307/4020468}}</ref> and took part in many activities that were not perceived as the norm for gentlewomen, such as opening and owning a [[colliery]].<ref name="BBC - The life and loves of Shibden Hall's Anne Lister" /> She was referred to as "Gentleman Jack" in some quarters.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Mavor |first=Elizabeth |title=Gentleman Jack of Halifax |journal=London Review of Books |date=4 February 1988 |volume=10 |issue=3 |publisher=LRB Ltd. |location=London |issn=0260-9592 |url=http://www.lrb.co.uk/v10/n03/elizabeth-mavor/gentleman-jack-from-halifax |accessdate=14 June 2010 }}</ref> Lawton and Lister were lovers for several years, including a period during which Lawton was married and had her husband's permission.<ref name="Rictor - First Modern Lesbian" />
Lister's subsequent affair with a wealthy heiress, Ann Walker, whom she met in 1832, was a story of local repute. The women took communion together on Easter Sunday 1834 in [[Holy Trinity Church, Goodramgate, York]], which in their view married them. The church, recognised by a [[blue plaque]], has been described as "an icon for what is interpreted as the site of the first lesbian marriage to be held in Britain."<ref name=beeb28jl18>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/jul/28/anne-lister-blue-plaque-lesbian-marriage-church |title=Recognition at last for Gentleman Jack, Britain's ‘first modern lesbian' |newspaper=The Guardian |date=28 July 2018 |author= Harriet Sherwood |accessdate= 3 September 2018}}</ref> The couple lived together at Shibden Hall until Lister's death in 1840. Walker's fortune was used to improve Shibden Hall and the property's waterfall and lake.<ref name="Crampton2013"/> Lister renovated Shibden Hall quite significantly to her own design.<ref name="BBC - The life and loves of Shibden Hall's Anne Lister" /> In 1838 she added a Gothic tower to the main house, to serve as her private library. She also had a tunnel dug under the building which allowed the staff to move about without disturbing her.<ref name="Crampton2013">{{cite news |last=Crampton |first=Caroline |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/culture/2013/11/lesbian-dead-sea-scrolls |title=The lesbian Dead Sea Scrolls: Anne Lister's diaries |work=[[New Statesman]] |location=London |date=2013-12-05 |accessdate=2014-08-25 }}</ref> In 1830 while travelling in France, Lister was the first woman to ascend [[Monte Perdido]] in the Aragonese [[Pyrenees]].<ref>{{cite book |first=Nanou |last=Saint-Lèbe |title=Les Femmes à la découverte des Pyrénées |location=Toulouse |publisher=Privat |year=2002 |language=French }}</ref> In 1838, she came back to the Pyrenees with Walker and completed the first "official" ascent of the [[Vignemale]] ({{Convert|3298|m|ft}}).<ref>{{cite book |first1=Ann |last1=Lister |title=Première ascension du Vignemale: le 7 août 1838 |author2=Maury, Luc (translator) |publisher=Cairn |year=2000 |isbn=2-912233-25-9 |language=French |location=Pau }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last = Ingham | first = Vivien | title = Anne Lister's Ascent of Vignemale | journal = Alpine Journal | volume = 73 | issue = 316–317 |page=199 | date = 1968 | url = http://alpinejournal.org.uk/Contents/Contents_1968_files/AJ%201968%20199-204%20Ingham%20Anne%20Lister.pdf | accessdate = 22 January 2011}} </ref> In France she was known as ''Ann Lister'' or ''Lady Lister'' only for this accomplishment. [[File:Saint Anns.JPG|thumb|right|250px|Anne Lister is buried in St Anne's church, [[Southowram]], West Yorkshire]]
==Death== Anne Lister died on 22 September 1840 aged 49 of a fever at Koutais (now [[Kutaisi]], Georgia) while travelling with Ann Walker.<ref>{{cite book |title= The Friend |first=Alan |last=Bray |publisher=University of Chicago Press |year=2003 |isbn=0-226-07180-4 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b6O01T7JsvQC&pg=PA283&dq=%22Anne+Lister%22+died+Georgia&as_brr=3&sig=ACfU3U1Onffjv9ARpwUW8JUei1Ued2KzZA |accessdate=3 August 2008 }}</ref> Walker, to whom ownership of Shibden Hall passed, had Lister's body embalmed and brought back to the UK, where she is buried in the parish church in [[Halifax, West Yorkshire]]. Ann Walker died in 1854 at her childhood home, Cliff Hill in Lightcliffe.
Throughout her life, Lister had a strong faith in the Anglican Church.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Clark|first=Anna|title=Anne Lister's Construction of Lesbian Identity|journal=Journal of the History of Sexuality |date=July 1996 |volume=7|issue=1|page=35}}</ref> Lister's family had a vault at the Halifax parish church where her remains were interred on 29 April 1841.<ref name="Leeds1882">{{cite news |title=The Shibden Hall Estate |work=Leeds Times |date=22 July 1882 |accessdate=5 February 2015 |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000336/18820722/024/0007 | via = [[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> Her tombstone was rediscovered in 2010 after being covered by a floor in 1879. The current family tomb is at St Anne's Church, [[Southowram]], where [[John Lister (UK politician)|John Lister]] is buried; he was the first to attempt the translation of Anne Lister's diaries.<ref name="Crampton2013"/>
In her will Lister's estate was left to her paternal cousins but Ann Walker was given a [[life interest]].<ref name="Leeds1882"/> After being declared insane, Walker spent some years in the care of Dr. Belcombe and, because of her mental state, was unable to make a valid will.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.york.ac.uk/borthwick/holdings/guides/research-guides/lgbt/anne-lister/|title=The Story of Anne Lister|last=|first=|date=|website=Borthwick Institute for Archives, The University of York|language=EN|access-date=2017-07-20}}</ref>
More than forty years after her death, while reporting on a dispute over the ownership of Shibden Hall, the ''Leeds Times'' stated 'Miss Lister's masculine singularities of character are still remembered'.<ref name="Leeds1882"/>
==Diaries== During her life, Anne wrote a four-million-word diary. It began in 1806 as scraps of paper, recording in secret code parcels sent to and from Eliza Raine, and eventually became the 26 Quarto volumes ending at her death in 1840. In addition to her handwriting being incredibly difficult to decipher,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Liddington|first=Jill|title=Anne Lister of Shibden Hall, Halifax (1791-1840): Her Diaries and the Historians|journal=History Workshop Journal|date=1993|volume=35|issue=1|pages=45–77|doi=10.1093/hwj/35.1.45}}</ref> around one-sixth of the diary is encrypted in a [[Simple substitution|simple code]] she and Eliza had devised, combining the Greek alphabet, zodiac, punctuation and mathematical symbols,<ref name="Rictor - First Modern Lesbian" /> and it describes quite graphically her lesbian nature and affairs, as well as the tactics she used for seduction. The diaries also contain her thoughts on the weather, social events, national events and her business interests. The majority of her diary deals with her daily life, and not merely her lesbianism,<ref name="BBC - The life and loves of Shibden Hall's Anne Lister" /> and provides detailed information on social, political and economic events of the time.
The code used in her diaries was deciphered by the last inhabitant of Shibden Hall, John Lister (1847–1933) and a friend of his, Arthur Burrell. When the content of the secret passages was revealed, Burrell advised John Lister to burn all the diaries. Lister did not take this advice, but instead continued to hide Anne Lister's diaries behind a panel at Shibden Hall.
In 2011, Lister's diaries were added to the [[UK Memory of the World Register|register]] of the [[UNESCO]] [[Memory of the World Programme]].<ref name="Crampton2013"/><ref name="UNESCOreg">{{cite web |url=http://www.unesco.org.uk/2011_uk_memory_of_the_world_register |title=UK Memory of the World Register |work=UK National Commission for UNESCO |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |date=2011 |accessdate=2014-08-25 }}</ref> The register citation notes that, while a valuable account of the times, it was the 'comprehensive and painfully honest account of lesbian life and reflections on her nature, however, which have made these diaries unique. They have shaped and continue to shape the direction of UK Gender Studies and Women’s History.'<ref name="UNESCOreg"/>
==Research== Work by Dorothy Thompson and Patricia Hughes in the late 1980s resulted in discovery of the first juvenile Lister diaries and decoding of the other two Lister codes.{{cn|date=October 2017}} Hughes self-published ''Anne Lister's Secret Diary for 1817'' (2006) and ''The Early Life of Miss Anne Lister and the Curious Tale of Miss Eliza Raine'' (2010), both of which make extensive use of other materials in the Lister archives including letters, diaries and ancillary documents.{{cn|date=October 2017}}
Helena Whitbread published some of the diaries in two volumes (1988 and 1992). Their graphic nature meant at first they were believed by some to be a hoax but documentary evidence has since established their authenticity.<ref name="Rictor - First Modern Lesbian" /> A biography by [[Jill Liddington]] appeared in 1994. In 2014 a conference was held at Shibden Hall which focused on Lister's life along with gender and sexuality in the nineteenth century.<ref>Anne Lister Conference{{cite web|title=The Inaugural Anne Lister Conference; women, gender and sexuality in the 19th Century|url=http://museums.calderdale.gov.uk/whatson/events/inaugural-anne-lister-conference-women-gender-and-sexuality-19th-century|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525201010/http://museums.calderdale.gov.uk/whatson/events/inaugural-anne-lister-conference-women-gender-and-sexuality-19th-century|archivedate=25 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> A biography by Angela Steidele in the German language was published in 2017.
==Popular culture== In 1994 the first episode of the [[BBC Two]] series ''A Skirt Through History'' titled ''A Marriage'' featured [[Julia Ford]] as Anne Lister, and [[Sophie Thursfield]] as Marianna Belcombe.<ref>[http://collections-search.bfi.org.uk/web/Details/ChoiceFilmWorks/150429369 BFI Database]</ref><ref>[http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/a3ebdbc07ab540b9b94a53beeb507e5d BBC Genome]</ref>
In 2010, [[BBC Two]] broadcast a production based on Lister's life, ''[[The Secret Diaries of Miss Anne Lister]]'', starring [[Maxine Peake]] as Lister.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2009/11_november/11/lister.shtml |title=BBC Two announces brand new drama: The Secret Diaries Of Miss Anne Lister |date=11 November 2009 |work=BBC Press Office |publisher=BBC |accessdate=1 February 2010 }}</ref> ''Revealing Anne Lister'', a documentary featuring [[Sue Perkins]], was broadcast on 31 May 2010 on [[BBC Two]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00snbkq |title=Revealing Anne Lister |work=BBC Two Programmes |publisher=BBC |accessdate=10 June 2010 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100604081329/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00snbkq| archivedate= 4 June 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
In 2012, on their second album, ''[[The Fragile (O'Hooley & Tidow album)|The Fragile]]'', chamber folk duo [[O'Hooley & Tidow]] ([[Belinda O'Hooley]] and Heidi Tidow) released a song about Anne Lister, which is called ''Gentleman Jack''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whensallymetsally.co.uk/entertainment/music-and-performance/interview-with-ohooley-and-tidow/|title=Music and Performance: Interview with O'Hooley and Tidow|publisher=When Sally Met Sally|date=12 September 2012|accessdate=15 September 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120917061810/http://www.whensallymetsally.co.uk/entertainment/music-and-performance/interview-with-ohooley-and-tidow/|archivedate=17 September 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In 2017 a historical drama called ''[[Gentleman Jack (TV series)|Gentleman Jack]]'' was announced, starring [[Suranne Jones]] as Anne Lister. It will focus on the life of Anne Lister.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2017/07/suranne-jones-star-sally-wainright-drama-series-hbo-bbc-1202131733/|title=Suranne Jones To Star In Sally Wainright Drama Series For HBO & BBC One|last=Petski|first=Denise|date=19 July 2017|work=Deadline|access-date=10 April 2018}}</ref><ref name=beeb28jl18/>
==Plaque== In 2018 a blue plaque with rainbow edging and wording "Gender-nonconforming entrepreneur. Celebrated marital commitment, without legal recognition, to Ann Walker in this church. Easter, 1834" was unveiled at Holy Trinity Church in York to honor her; it is York's first [[LGBT]] history plaque.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-york-north-yorkshire-44938819 |title=Plaque in York honours 'first modern lesbian' Anne Lister|website=BBC News |date=24 July 2018|author=<!--not stated--> |accessdate=2018-07-28}}</ref> The wording was criticised for not including "lesbian", and it was agreed to change it.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-york-north-yorkshire-45397536 |title=Anne Lister: Plaque wording to change after 'lesbian' row |website=BBC News|date= September 2018 |author= |accessdate= 3 September 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|35em}}
==Sources== * Green, Muriel, ''Miss Lister of Shibden Hall: Selected Letters (1800–1840)''. (The Book Guild, Ltd., 1992) *[[Jill Liddington|Liddington, Jill]]. ''Presenting the Past: Anne Lister of Halifax, 1791–1840''. (Pennine Pens, 1994) * Liddington, Jill, ''Female Fortune: Land, Gender and Authority: The Anne Lister Diaries and Other writings, 1833–36'' (Rivers Oram Press, 1998) *[[Helena Whitbread|Whitbread, Helena]], ''I Know My Own Heart: The Diaries of Anne Lister 1791–1840''. ([[Virago Press|Virago]], 1988) *Vicinus, Martha, ''Intimate friends: women who loved women, 1778–1928''. (University of Chicago Press, 2004) *Hughes, Patricia, ''Anne Lister's Secret Diary for 1817'' (Hues Books Ltd 2006) *Hughes, Patricia, ''The Secret Life of Miss Anne Lister and the Curious Tale of Miss Eliza Raine'' (Hues Books Ltd 2010) *Whitbread, Helena, ''No Priest But Love: Excerpts from the Diaries of Anne Lister''. (NYU Press, 1993) *Steidele, Angela, ''Anne Lister. Eine erotische Biographie''. (Matthes & Seitz Berlin, 2017)
==External links== {{Library resources box|by=yes|viaf=69113357}} *[http://www.annelister.co.uk/diary-archives Anne Lister's encoded diary] — shows scanned images of Anne Lister's encoded diary pages *[http://www.sappho.com/letters/a_lister.html Anne Lister Page at Sappho.com] — provides excerpts of her translated diaries *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080926210046/http://www.historytoherstory.org.uk/index.php?targetid=5 Anne Lister page at From History to Her Story: Yorkshire Women's lives on-line] — provides excerpts of her translated diaries, as well as images from the original *[http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Lister_grave.JPG/800px-Lister_grave.JPG Anne Lister's Family Grave site] *[http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Saint_Anns.JPG/800px-Saint_Anns.JPG Saint Ann's Church] *{{UK National Archives ID}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090501062045/http://www.archives.wyjs.org.uk/ The West Yorkshire Archive Service] – Holds the Anne Lister Diaries at the Calderdale office
{{Portal|Biography|Cryptography|LGBT}} {{Authority control}}

[[File:Akt jedności.jpg|thumb|right|240px|Act of Unity signed during the AutografExpo.]]
'''AutografExpo''' was an exhibition of contemporary signed documents and autographs of public interest in [[Poland]]. The main organizer and promoter was forensic expert [[Jaroslaw Pijarowski]].
Over a three-year period, a planning committee examined and chose 2,000 items from 75,000. It first opened July 5, 2008, in the Museum of Diplomacy and Polish Refugees, in the city of [[Bydgoszcz]].
The exhibition also featured a display, "Act of Unity," a special signed document that commemorated the tenth anniversary of the creation of the [[Kuyavian-Pomeranian Voivodeship|Kuyavian-Pomeranian]] provincial region on 1 January 1999.
[[Franciszek Starowieyski]] received an award of the most interesting graphical representation of contemporary autographs.
After the exhibition, [[Jaroslaw Pijarowski]] received a special diploma and award from the head of the city of [[Bydgoszcz]], [[Konstanty Dombrowicz]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wok.bydgoszcz.com/imprezy_opis.php?i%3D24997 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-09-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708110006/http://www.wok.bydgoszcz.com/imprezy_opis.php?i=24997 |archivedate=2011-07-08 |df= }}</ref> <ref>http://miasta.gazeta.pl/bydgoszcz/1,35588,5284235,Ogladaj_autografy_slaw.html</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bydgoszcz.pl/miasto/press_room/kalendarium_archiwum2008.aspx?page%3D7 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-09-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090516015941/http://www.bydgoszcz.pl/miasto/press_room/kalendarium_archiwum2008.aspx?page=7 |archivedate=2009-05-16 |df= }}</ref> <ref>http://www.bydgoszcz.pl/miasto/wspolpraca_z_zagranica/Kalendarium_2006-09.aspx?page=3</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bydgoszcz.uw.gov.pl/index.php?option%3Dcom_content%26task%3Dview%26id%3D13%26Itemid%3D17 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-09-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110911125710/http://www.bydgoszcz.uw.gov.pl/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=13&Itemid=17 |archivedate=2011-09-11 |df= }}</ref> <ref>http://www.express.bydgoski.pl/look/article.tpl?IdLanguage=17&IdPublication=2&NrIssue=919&NrSection=1&NrArticle=103532&IdTag=2603</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * http://www.muzeum.ukw.edu.pl//jednostka/muzeum_dyplomacji/ - website of Museum of Diplomacy and Polish Refugees in Poland
{{DEFAULTSORT:Autografexpo}} [[Category:Documents]]
